oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Nashville Record Review Artist Interviews 1982 - D
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recordings of phone interviews with various artists hosted by Al Risen. Recording features: Richard Sterban, Charley Pride, John Hartford, Ronnie Rogers, Michael Murphey, Joe Thrasher, Earl Thomas Conley, and Sylvia. Item is listed as part D of the 1982 Nashville Radio Review artist interviews.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Al Risen
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Al Risen introduces Richard Sterban who discusses the success of Bobby Sue and Elvira -- (01:32) Risen and Sterban discuss the inspiration for "I Wish You Could Have Turned My Head" -- (02:49) Risen radio spot introduction for "I Wish You Could Have Turned My Head" -- (02:58) Risen introduces Charley Pride who discusses his upcoming schedule of shows; additionally, Risen and Pride discuss the Texas Vocal Company -- (04:29) "You're so Good (When You're Bad)" is discussed by Pride to be a memorable song, and Pride reflects on what he looks for in a song -- (05:48) Risen radio spot introduction for "You're So Good (When You're Bad)" -- (05:53) Risen introduces John Hartford who discusses with Risen how he is a steam boat pilot -- (07:15) Hartford reflects on being on the Glen Campbell Show -- (07:53) Hartford reflects on when Campbell had heard Hartford's "Gentle on My Mind;" additionally Risen and Hartford discuss what difficulties "Gentle on My Mind" faced -- (10:45) Risen radio spot introduction for "Gentle on My Mind" -- (10:55) Risen introduces Ronnie Rogers who discusses his Nashville upbringing; additionally, Rogers discusses his relationship with Ed Bruce -- (12:28) Tommy West is discussed by Rogers and Risen -- (13:01) Risen and Rogers discuss "Gonna Take My Angel Out Tonight; additionally Rogers reflects on the comparisons the record faces -- (14:35) Rogers reflects on why he wrote "Happy Country Birthday" for his wife -- (15:23) Risen radio spot introduction for "Happy Country Birthday" -- (15:28) Risen introduces Michael Murphey who discusses a bit of his musical career -- (17:09) Murphey's next single is discussed; additionally, Murphey reflects on the after-hours session that led to "What's Forever For" -- (19:07) Risen radio spot introduction for "What's Forever For" -- (19:17) Risen introduces Joe Thrasher who discusses a bit of the Thrasher Brothers' musical career -- (20:25) Risen invites the comparison of the Thrasher Brothers to the Oak Ridge Boys -- (21:03) Thrasher discusses where he and the band members live -- (21:40) "One Day at a Time" is told by Thrasher to be the biggest gospel song the Thrasher Brothers had released; additionally, the Thrasher Brothers' television show is discussed -- (22:45) "Still the One" is told by Thrasher to be one of his favorites -- (23:26) Risen radio spot introduction for "Still the One" -- (23:31) Risen introduces Earl Thomas Conley who discusses a bit of his touring schedule -- (24:06) Risen addresses the success of "Somewhere Between Right and Wrong," and Conley addresses the writers on his track -- (24:51) Conley discusses "I Have Loved You Girl," among others, from his new album -- (25:35) Conley reflects on his families current successes -- (26:27) Conley discusses the woman's perspective of "Somewhere Between Right and Wrong" -- (26:53) Risen radio spot introduction for "Somewhere Between Right and Wrong" -- (26:59) Risen introduces Sylvia who discusses living in Kokomo, Indiana -- (27:58) Sylvia and Risen discuss how Sylvia's parents' lives had changed -- (28:34) Sylvia discusses her upcoming projects including: Country Jamboree, and creating her new house -- (29:50) Risen reflects on how "Nobody" was created -- (31:00) Risen radio spot introduction for "Nobody"
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Sterban, Richard, 1943-; Pride, Charley; Pride, Charley, 1938-; Hartford, John; Rogers, Ronnie; Murphey, Michael, 1945-; Thrasher Brothers; Conley, Earl Thomas; Sylvia, 1956-;
